Subject:Oscar Lopez Rivera and Norberto Gonzalez Claudio
Message:


The ProLibertad Freedom Campaign
www.ProLibertadweb.com
ProlIbertad Hotline: 718-601-4751
 
 
Below this message is an announcement for the May 28th: Free Oscar Lopez Rivera community March in the South Bronx, please scroll down to the end to see it!
 
 
On Friday May 20th, Puerto Rican Political Prisoner Norberto Gonz·lez Claudio wll be arraigned at the Hartford Conn Federal Court House at 3pm. We are asking people to stay alert. 
 
 
 
 

 
Biography of Norberto Gonz·lez Claudio
 
Born in Vega Baja on May 27, 1945, the second youngest of 6 siblings: 2 women, Mercedes and MarÌa Magdalena, and 3 men, Avelino, Orlando and Wilfredo. He lived in the neighborhood of Almirante Sur with his mother Cristina Claudio Narv·ez and his father Antonio Gonz·lez Vega until he was 7 years old. The family then moved to the neighborhood of Rio Abajo to ìthe Gonz·lez farmî (his family), where he stayed until he married Elda Santiago PÈrez in 1979. Together they had 3 children: Elda Cristina, Susana and Carlos, and they also raised Eldaís sons Pedro and RamÛn as their own. 
 
During his childhood, he played and ran around like every child does. His father called him Captain. He always had fond memories of his father, but his mother was someone very special for him. Her serenity, firmness, strength, wisdom, the strength of a working woman that his mother embodied have been his inheritance and his pride. With her he learned love, sensitivity, and simplicity, as well as to not give in to the powerful. 
 
He joined the struggle for social justice and the independence of Puerto Rico in the decade of the 60's while he was a university student. He was a member of the Federation of Pro Independence Students (FUPI), the Pro Independence Movement (MPI) and the Puerto Rican Socialist Party (PSP). He got his political training in the Arecibo region. He was known in his town for selling the newspaper Claridad. 
 
He had a post on a corner of Betances Street in the center of his town, and put on activities of protest music in the plaza. He actively participated in the Vega Bajaís Garbage Collectors strike in 1970, in the student strikes of 1970 and 1971 at the University of Puerto Rico, and in the protests against the mines in Adjuntas, where he camped out for several months. 
 
 He was in clandestinity since 1985 for defending his people, his homeland, his nation, and fighting for socialism because he thinks it is the just economic model for all peoples. 
 
 He is in solidarity with Latin American countries in their restorative struggles and with all countries that struggle for their freedom and for socialism. He fervently believes and struggles for patriotic unity. ìWe must unite on everything we can agree on. Our differences should be left for internal discussions within each organization,î he insists.
He is a poet. He writes of his family, life, the homeland, youth, and his eternal love: his wife, to whom, as if a premonition of his future, he dedicated since the very moment they got married Don Pablo Nerudaís The Letter on the Road.
    
Now, he is captured by the repressive forces of the northamerican government who seek to criminalize the struggle for the independence of our people and those who defend our Puerto Rican nation. 
 
 
 
Arrest of Gonz·lez Claudio was an FBI ìshowî 
By Perla Franco
Published Tuesday May 17, 2011 
http://www.claridadpuertorico.com/content.html?news=FF101593E35035283AEF563401BC126E
 
ìNorberto Gonz·lez Claudio has dedicated his life to the struggle for the independence of Puerto Rico. He is a patriot, not a terrorist. Keeping a nation under the colonial yoke is a crime against humanity, according to the United Nations. Thus, the struggle to end oppression and colonialism is patriotism, as has been proved in liberation struggles that all the free countries of the world have waged. We condemn the arrest of this patriot and are in solidarity with him and his family.î
 
With this convincing stipulation in a press release, more than a dozen independentista organizations convened a protest last Friday May 13 in front of the Federal Court on ChardÛn Avenue in Hato Rey, while inside the building Norberto Gonz·lez Claudioís extradition hearing was taking place in magistrate Bruce McGiverinís courtroom. 
 
When family members entered McGiverinís courtroom, Gonz·lez Claudio was already there, his hands and feet shackled, dressed in a beige jumpsuit and phosphorescent orange tennis shoes, the uniform the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC). His wife, sister-in-law, children and grandchildren were seated on the opposite side of the courtroom. An agent entered and handed the family ìan object of value the arrestee had when he was detained,î and went on to hand his wife a wedding ring. When his five year old grandson noticed that his grandfather was in the room, he said out loud, ìlook at Grandpa over there.î A little later, the hearing, which would last around two and a half hours, began. 
 
The hearing began with the magistrate denying the request from one of the defense lawyers, Juan Matos, to postpone the hearing because he hadnít had enough time to meet with Gonz·lez Claudio. 
 
FBI agent gives his version of the arrest
Assistant U.S. Attorney Warren V·zquezí first witness was an ìFBI special agentî who identified himself as David Gonz·lez. He detailed that he was in San Juan when a task force located in Guavate, Cayey called him to say they had seen someone they thought was Gonz·lez Claudio. He assured that this group was involved in efforts unrelated to Gonz·lez Claudioís arrest. Later, in response to cross-examination, he said it took him some 25 minutes to get to the place where Gonz·lez Claudio was exercising in a community park on Highway 184, and that he identified him by the one droopy eyelid Gonz·lez Claudio was known to have, and by his left leg being much shorter than his right leg. 
 
The agent claimed to be familiar with the file of the accused, who he identified as a Machetero, an organization he said was founded in 1975, and which in 2005 the U.S. government labeled as terrorist. He added that the charges against him were for conspiracy to commit robbery. He stated that when he approached him to arrest him, he said, ìhey mister, look at me, come with me.î He said Gonz·lez Claudio took a deep breath, looked behind, and the agent said, ìdonít do this to me,î and that Gonz·lez Claudio moved his head and went toward the steps where the agent told him ìsit down.î He said Gonz·lez Claudio smiled and said, ìyou caught me.î According to the agent, Gonz·lez Claudio had several false names, including Carmelo VÈlez Moya, which he used to get a drivers license at the end of 1990. 
 
According to his story, after the arrest, he was taken to the office of the head of the FBI, Luis Fraticelli. The defense attorney asked why he was taken there, since that isnít the procedure. The agent responded that heíd received orders from his supervisor to do that. He related that while there, Fraticelli asked him if he needed medication, and if he was in good health, and he commented that he looked like his brother Avelino, to which the arrestee allegedly responded, ìweíre from the same blood.î He said Fraticelli asked if he wanted to speak with his family, and that Gonz·lez Claudio said he did. From right there, with the speakerphone on, he called his wife and told her he was in Fraticelliís office, and that he was ok. From there they took him to booking, and when they asked him to sign, the arrestee signed his name as Norberto Gonz·lez. 
 
The government also called probation officer Patricia EncarnaciÛn Miranda, who said that when she interviewed the arrestee and told him to sign his name, he wrote Norberto Gonz·lez. The defense argued, and it was corroborated by the agent who conducted the arrest, that Gonz·lez Claudio was never read his rights, not when they arrested him, and not when Fraticelli tried to talk with him, questioning him, which the defense said violated his right not to incriminate himself.
 
In closing arguments, the defense attorney urged that until extradition, Gonz·lez Claudio be placed under 24 hour a day house arrest. But the magistrate said the accused was a ìdangerousî person due to ìhis philosophical vision and that of the political organization he belongs to.î
 
At the end of the hearing, his family, guarded by an agent, was instructed not to leave the courtroom until the accused had left. Gonz·lez Claudio walked by them, leaning his body and throwing a kiss to his five year old grandson, who at the time was two or three steps away. The child responded, shouting, ìI love you, Grandpa,î and immediately asked the attorney who came after, ìWhy didnít they let my grandpa go?î The attorney answered, ìI tried, but I couldnít. They decided not to let him go.î And the child said, as if it were a childís game, ìwell, you had to hide.î
 
Agent claims they found weapons
Agent Gonz·lez added, in response to the U.S. Attorneyís questions, that in the search of Gonz·lez Claudioís alleged residence in Guavate, at his bedside they found two revolvers and a loaded automatic rifle with additional ammunition, in addition to two bulletproof vests. The agent didnít answer defense questions about the number of agents who participated in the operation, as the government objected that it was ìirrelevant,î and the magistrate sustained the objection. During cross-examination, the defense managed to obtain information that the agent had been working for two years for the U.S. Attorney in San Juan, and that prior to this arrest he hadnít done any other work in that place. Sometimes the agent, who responded to the governmentís questions with aplomb and firmness, responded to cross-examination looking more disjointed, confused, and nervous, and asked that questions be repeated. At those times, he looked at the Assistant U.S. Attorney as if he were looking for approval. It seemed as though he hadnít read the charges against Gonz·lez Claudio. 
 
Family embraces the arrestee
A second government witness was Samuel Santana, who identified himself as a National Security special agent in San Juan, and who claimed to have been investigating the Macheteros since 1995. He said that since then he had references about Gonz·lez Claudio, whose 1985 photo he carried with him. He said he was the one who received Gonz·lez Claudioís wife when she came to the federal building after his arrest. And he said he recognized Norbertoís brother Orlando, who he approached and asked if he wanted to see his brother, to which Orlando said he did, because he hadnít seen him in years. He stated that he allowed them both, along with Norbertoís brother-in-law, to be present during Norbertoís booking. He stated that Orlando hugged Norberto, and that Norberto smiled but didnít otherwise move, as he was handcuffed. 
 
The federal charges against Norberto Gonz·lez Claudio at the time of his arrest on May 10 donít directly tie him to the theft of $7.2 million from Wells Fargo in Connecticut. Essentially he is charged with the FBI identifying him as a member of the clandestine independentista organization The Macheteros. Many consider that his arrest was an FBI show to improve the agencyís image.

chicagotribune.com
Puerto Rican community seeks prisoner's release
By Margaret Ramirez
Tribune reporter

7:25 PM CDT, May 29, 2011
Advertisement

With prayer, song and calls for freedom, dozens of Puerto Rican community members and human rights activists gathered today to mark the 30th year in prison for Puerto Rican nationalist Oscar Lopez Rivera and called for his release.

Lopez Rivera, now 68, is a gray-haired vestige of a long-gone era in America, when a group known as the F.A.L.N. (Spanish for the Armed Forces of National Liberation) fought for Puerto Rico's independence from the U.S.

More than a dozen FALN members were convicted and imprisoned in the 1980s on various charges including seditious conspiracy and armed robbery. In 1999, President Bill Clinton granted clemency to nearly all the prisoners and released them.

Lopez Rivera, who is serving a 70-year sentence in a federal prison in Terre Haute, Ind., is now the last remaining Puerto Rican prisoner.

In recent months, the National Boricua Human Rights Network and other activists have launched a national campaign to urge President Barack Obama to commute his sentence. In addition to a prayer vigil and rally in Chicago, events were also held in New York, Los Angeles, Cleveland, Philadelphia and Puerto Rico.

At the Sunday prayer service held at Lincoln United Methodist Church in Chicago, the prisoner's sister, Zenaida Lopez, said her brother has done his time and should be allowed to come home.

In addition to his sister, Lopez Rivera has a daughter, Clarissa, who lives in Puerto Rico and a granddaughter, Karina, who is a student at the University of Chicago.

ìThere's one thing that's forgotten in this struggle -- and it's that Oscar is human,î Zenaida Lopez said. ìHe's a brother. He's a father. He's a grandfather. He's a son. He's loved deeply by his family.

îWe have to struggle to see that he is released, so that he becomes part of the family once again. It is our dream. It is our hope. It is something that we talk about every single day.

Also at the prayer service, two activists, Michael Reyes and Matt McCanna arrived after completing a 10-day, 200-mile walk from the federal prison in Indiana to Chicago.

The FALN was involved in a series of bombings in New York and Chicago, including the 1975 bombing of the Fraunces Tavern in Manhattan that killed four and injured more than 60 others.

Lopez was not convicted for a role in the Tavern incident.

In the Puerto Rican community, Lopez Rivera, a Vietnam War veteran and community organizer, is widely regarded as hero. But, others view him as an unrepentant terrorist.

Those opponents said his release would send the wrong message about terrorism.

In February, the U.S. Parole Commission denied Lopez Rivera parole and released a statement that said: ìWe have to look at whether release would depreciate the seriousness of the offenses or promote disrespect for the law, whether release would jeopardize public safety and the specific characteristics of the offender.î

Even so, his attorney Jan Susler, remains hopeful of his release. She noted that three previous U.S. presidents have commuted sentences of Puerto Rican prisoners including presidents Harry Truman, Jimmy Carter and Clinton.

marramirez@...



 
 
Carlos Alberto talks about Oscar LÛpez Rivera
By C·ndida Cotto
Published: Tuesday May 24, 2011 
http://www.claridadpuertorico.com/content.html?news=22D0072C9F3A36D03E2390719D2DC805 
 
On Monday, May 9, 2011, the United States Parole Commission denied parole to Puerto Rican political prisoner Oscar LÛpez Rivera, who on May 29 will mark 30 years of a cruel imprisonment.
 
Already here in the Homeland, ex political prisoner Carlos Alberto Torres is about to complete a year since his release from prison. Comrades from the same struggle, both from Chicago, the experience of their years in prison and facing the procedure before the Parole Commission, make Carlos Alberto and Oscar LÛpez Rivera two sides of the same coin.
 
Claridad talked with Carlos Alberto about his reaction to LÛpez Riveraís procedure before the Parole Commission. 
 
Imprisonment
How do you face prison? is the question posed to Carlos Alberto in view of the fact that Oscar LÛpez is still in prison after 30 years. In a low, serene tone, he described for us: ìWhen youíre in prison, youíre alone. Although there are compaÒeros, you are alone because the government made sure, with the exception of the women, that all of us were going to be in different prisons. They didnít want us together, in part because their strategy was ëweíre going to see how we can break this individual, change his opinions, or extinguish his fervor.í They put you in a kind of isolation, not only separation throughout the United States, but that isolation ... you feel it when you arrive at a place, ëwow,í what am I doing in Alabama? Or what am I doing in California? At the end of the day, youíre alone, youíre surrounded by other people, but theyíre not your compaÒeros, theyíre not your family, theyíre people you donít know, maybe people you are suspicious of. You make friends, and even though there is support, a lot of affection, itís always with certain caution ... separation.î
 
The support you receive from the outside is what makes the difference. ìThat strengthens you, but at the end of the day you have to know who you are, why youíre there, and you have to have a strong sense of yourself as a person who struggles, and not allow the conditions to separate you from that. 
 
ìWith Oscar, Iím sure, knowing him, that he is a person of verticality, his character, his principles, he is one of the most generous people you will ever know in your life. He is that type of man who thinks of others, of the collective, before thinking of himself. Heís an individual we all admire as a natural leader, a real man. His conduct confirms it and affirms it every day. A man of struggle, a man of conscience, brilliant, of incredible intelligence.î
 
The last time Carlos Alberto saw Oscar was April 4, 1980, the day he was arrested with the group of then-members of the Armed Forces of National Liberation (FALN). Oscar was arrested the following year, on May 29, 1981, and has been in prison ever since. ìWhen I knew him, I already had a mustache,î recalls the current resident of Camuy.
 
He knew Oscar at the beginning of the ë70's, when he was at the University of Illinois. ìHe noticed me because I was a young kid. He went to speak to my parents about issues in the community. I was already interested, had a social conscience. I grew up thinking it was natural to integrate into community work. Thatís the context in which I started to work with Oscar. His influence over me was total. I immediately recognized that he was a person of conviction, commitment, with energy. He reminded me and made me think a lot about my concept of don Pedro (Albizu Campos) who put the struggle and the people first. Thatís exactly how Oscar was, putting the struggle and the people before his own comfort.î
 
Like a cruel game, the conditions imposed on the Puerto Rican political prisoners didnít allow Carlos Alberto to stay in contact with his eleven compaÒeros freed in 1999, nor with Oscar during the five years they were on conditions. The compaÒeros, now free of all conditions, can communicate among themselves and with Oscar. 
 
In light of your experience, did you ever doubt that Oscar LÛpezí case would turn out the way it did?
 
ìIn Oscarís case, we were all hopeful. I was really almost convinced because my experience in prison taught me that if itís six in the morning and time for sunrise, thatís what will happen, but also when youíre in prison you always have to have reservations, because anything can happen.
 
As for his reasons to be cautiously optimistic, he commented that he was the only one who in 1999 wasnít offered a sentence commutation; Oscar was offered release if he served 10 more years, which would have been in 2009. ìWe already know that he took a principled position, even though he told everyone else to accept. I figured out that the quarrel was with me. When I went for parole, they treated me like any other social prisoner. There was no extraordinary procedure. They conducted themselves ëwell.í I expected something like that would happen with Oscar. I said, ëwell, obviously there isnít such a strong resistance. The man will have served 30 years.í Under the law, any person sentenced to more than 45 years, who has good conduct, who hasnít been a risk to society, has the right to parole. That was the criteria they used with me, and itís the law.î
 
He immediately questioned what it means to be, or to not be, a risk to society. ìIn my case, from what I know about how hearings go, Iíd say with few exceptions they treated me like they treat everyone else, which is why I felt hopeful. Obviously I assumed that they would see that Oscar had served 30 years, there was no reason to treat Oscar differently. I was in prison for 30 years. Iíve talked with hundreds if not thousands of men who have been to parole hearings over the years. I had more or less an idea how they were. Iíve never heard of a case like Oscarís, where they take you chain up. It was an Inquisition.î
 
From a political perspective, he pointed out that it wasnít anticipated that the right wing in the United States would move in that way. He called attention to the fact that one of those who opposed the confirmation of the current U.S. Attorney General Eric Holder, said during Oscarís hearing that if theyíd known that he ñ Torres ñ were going to the Parole Commission, they would have reacted in the same way. 
 
ìThe Commission is an agency of the United States government. They arenít sympathetic with us; they are sympathetic with the system. There was truly a lot of work done to demonstrate to the Parole Commission that there was support among the people, that there was support in the Puerto Rican community from different interest groups who supported Oscarís release. At the moment of truth, they took sides. I think that the work that was done this time was remarkable. The difference was that now there was resistance from the right, and that agency is going to respond to the United States right before it will respond to the Puerto Rican community or to the Puerto Rican people in general,î he reflected. 
 
Like what happens in hardball, this hasnít ended, which is why Carlos Alberto insisted on how very important it is that Oscar continue receiving letters from friends, students, receiving calls, publications, postcards, information about the various activities. ìThat fills you up. You get your perspective back. If you were feeling a little depressed, in those moments you see Claridad, information about activities in New York, Philadelphia, Chicago, about the Grito de Lares ... you say, ëIím ok; theyíre working on it; we are struggling; they havenít forgotten about me.í Thatís what we have to do, to let the government know that even though they made that decision, weíre going to keep struggling, weíre going to keep organizing, weíre going to keep inviting people who havenít participated to participate, that weíre going to be with this compaÒero until he is release, period.î

®El desafiante retorno de Manuel Zelaya a Honduras®

 

Dr. Darsi Ferret

La Habana, Cuba. 6 de junio de 2011.

 

El actual presidente hondureÒo, Porfirio Lobo, ha cedido a las presiones de un grupo presidencial latinoamericano que a˙n carga con la agenda del trasnochado populismo. Y asÌ, otra vez vuelve a la carga el agotado proyecto subversivo del ALBA, el mismo que ya se rompiÛ los colmillos en su intentona de violentar la ConstituciÛn de esa hermana rep˙blica, hace apenas 3 aÒos.

Con el extravagante acto que se televisÛ desde Cartagena, Colombia, el ex presidente Manuel Zelaya, estimulado en su poca disimulada arrogancia y oportunismo, fue incitado a volver a las andadas. Ahora, con plena impunidad. En esa reuniÛn estaban presentes algunos de los mandatarios que m·s alentaron al depuesto presidente a forzar su ilegal reelecciÛn en el poder. Fueron, adem·s, los que luego trataron de provocar una intervenciÛn armada en Honduras para sojuzgar a los poderes p˙blicos que defendieron la independencia y el orden constitucional. Los mismos que hicieron lo imposible por aislar a la pequeÒa naciÛn centroamericana, logrando la vergonzosa decisiÛn de expulsarla de la OEA y su ostracismo en el continente. Y en el presente,  los que han intimidado o convencido al dÈbil presidente Lobo, electo limpiamente en las urnas, a menoscabar la defensa de la soberanÌa que su pueblo le otorgara en representaciÛn.

Esa soberanÌa se manifestÛ continua y claramente despuÈs de la destituciÛn constitucional de Zelaya. Miles de hondureÒos, vestidos de blanco para mostrar su inconfundible  apego a la paz,  llenaron plazas y avenidas de distintas ciudades de su paÌs, manifestando una clara muestra de apoyo a la acciÛn de los poderes p˙blicos para defender su independencia. 

A la luz de esos hechos indudables, no se puede justificar la reacciÛn de permanente rechazo de la OEA a la reinclusiÛn de Honduras. Mucho menos es cuestionable la legitimidad del gobernante Porfirio Lobo. Por ello, resulta sospechosa la debilidad que lo ha arrastrado a plegarse a los intereses del ALBA. 

El origen de todo el diferendo en Honduras ha sido permanentemente tergiversado. Se persiste en calificar de golpe de estado la demociÛn de Zelaya, y se descarta la razÛn por la cual los poderes p˙blicos actuaron contra Èl: el hecho flagrante de que a sabiendas violaba la misma carta magna que le permitiÛ ser elegido presidente indiscutible de la naciÛn y que jurara defender. En lugar de ello, insistiÛ en intentar saltarse la prohibiciÛn constitucional de convocar a un referendo para cambiar dicha carta magna a su favor, buscando la reelecciÛn prohibida. Si antes que Èl alguien hubiera promovido un cambio constitucional al estilo de Zelaya para reducirle a la mitad el perÌodo de la presidencia que Èste disfrutaba, sin dudas no le hubiera temblado el pulso al Sr. ex. presidente para ordenar el arresto del atrevido y acusarlo de atentado contra la patria. 

A algunos les parecer· que proceder contra Èl por ese mismo delito es injustificado, pero no se puede olvidar el simple hecho de que son los hondureÒos los que mejor pueden categorizar un asunto de tal magnitud en su propio paÌs. øO el tan citado argumento de la soberanÌa es un concepto relativo, a la medida de a quiÈn y cÛmo le toque? Para mayor aclaraciÛn del asunto, el supuesto golpe de estado no resultÛ ser identificable como tal. La historia demuestra que cuando ocurre un golpe de estado, toma el poder un grupo de militares o civiles fuertemente rodeados y apoyados por los milites, se suspenden las garantÌas constitucionales, se aplazan por tiempo indeterminado las funciones de los poderes legislativos y judiciales, se declara el estado de sitio y se prohÌbe la acciÛn de los partidos polÌticos. øOcurriÛ algo asÌ en Honduras?

Por el contrario, con el apoyo abrumador de todos los partidos polÌticos representados en el Congreso, de los poderes judiciales y del masivo apoyo, sostenido por meses, del pueblo y las organizaciones de la sociedad civil hondureÒa, se mandÛ a los militares (a esos mismos que Zelaya les invadiera ilegal e impunemente sus bases, acompaÒado por una gavilla de sus seguidores), y detuvieron al presidente en una acciÛn policial incruenta. øA quiÈn se iba a enviar para trincar al montaraz mandatario? øA un ujier? Y decidieron sacarlo del paÌs porque todos los representantes democr·ticamente elegidos por el pueblo estaban de acuerdo en que era la mejor soluciÛn al penoso y desagradable problema. Entonces asumiÛ el poder Roberto Micheletti, el presidente del Congreso, como le correspondÌa por orden constitucional. No se suspendieron las garantÌas constitucionales, no se declarÛ el estado de sitio, no se impidiÛ la labor de los partidos. La prensa funcionÛ libremente, asÌ como la libertad de tr·nsito y opiniÛn. øCÛmo se puede calificar esa situaciÛn de golpe de estado? 

Las elecciones que siguieron al cabo de los seis meses justos prometidos por Micheletti fueron libres, multipartidistas y las de mayor participaciÛn en la historia del paÌs. Y pese a los in˙tiles esfuerzos subversivos de los simpatizantes y enviados del ALBA, unas de las m·s limpias que se recuerdan en CentroamÈrica. Porfirio Lobo ganÛ el poder otorgado por el soberano compitiendo con otros adversarios polÌticos de diversas tendencias. øA quÈ viene, entonces, el rechazo  y la condena a la pequeÒa naciÛn? En esas condiciones de plena libertad para elegir, øcÛmo puede alguien atreverse a cuestionar y decidir mejor que los propios hondureÒos sobre la legitimidad de quiÈn los debe gobernar? Midiendo con esa misma vara, øcÛmo se aceptaron las ˙ltimas e irregulares demociones presidenciales en AmÈrica Latina? øCÛmo no se cuestiona permanentemente la legitimidad de la dictadura militar cubana?

La historia reciente demuestra que las elecciones anticipadas dan una posibilidad legal v·lida y por consenso a los callejones sin salida que ocurren en las sociedades modernas. Las demociones presidenciales de los ˙ltimos veinte aÒos en el continente, mucho m·s calificables como conspiraciones de grupos regulares, y no como un rotundo y masivo rechazo  popular al desgobierno (tales como los que en la actualidad se presencian en los paÌses ·rabes), han tenido soluciÛn y reconocimiento como aceptables mediante el mÈtodo de elecciones convocadas en un tiempo prudencial. AsÌ ocurriÛ tres veces en Ecuador, una en Bolivia y otra en Argentina. Los desafueros, reales o exagerados, de presidentes electos como  Abdal· Bucaram, Jamil Mahuad,  Lucio GutiÈrrez,  Gonzalo S·nchez de Losada y  Fernando de la Rua, dieron pie suficiente para que, en confusos motines  de grupos de un marcado extremismo, los mandatarios abandonaran precipitadamente su puesto marchando al extranjero,  y  asÌ se evitara un mayor derramamiento de sangre.

Es curioso como los gobiernos,  medios de informaciÛn y analistas continentales se han negado  a reconocer esa misma soluciÛn en el caso m·s que legal de sucesiÛn presidencial en Honduras. En lugar de develar  crÌticamente la corrupciÛn del ex mandatario y sus intentos conspirativos contra la voluntad de la naciÛn, se amarraron fuerte e histÈricamente a la versiÛn ALBA de los hechos, dando por sentado que habÌa ocurrido un golpe de estado y no una defensa de la ConstituciÛn y la soberanÌa.

  EspaÒa traiciona a los disidentes cubanos 

MARY ANASTASIA O'GRADY 

MADRID-A pesar de una tasa de desempleo de 21% y una la amenaza de una crisis en su deuda en el horizonte, EspaÒa todavÌa es un paÌs considerado como uno de los grandes destinos turÌsticos del mundo. Claro, a menos que usted sea un prisionero cubano de conciencia que fue deportado y depositado aquÌ por la dictadura militar de La Habana. En ese caso, la vida como un extraÒo en la soleada PenÌnsula IbÈrica es econÛmica y psicolÛgicamente sombrÌa. 

En los ˙ltimos 11 meses el rÈgimen cubano ha retirado abruptamente 115 presos polÌticos de sus celdas y los ha desterrado a EspaÒa, llamando a su exilio "liberaciÛn". Muchos de ellos son parte de un grupo llamado "los 75" que fueron detenidos en marzo de 2003 por actividades como reunir firmas para una peticiÛn de democracia, encabezar marchas pacÌficas, o escribir para diarios independientes. Se les permitiÛ irse con sus familiares cercanos y llevarse una muda de ropa de Cuba pero no despedirse de sus amigos y del resto de su familia y no se les expidiÛ un pasaporte. Algunos de ellos han tratado de obtener el status de refugiados polÌticos pero el gobierno espaÒol no ha estado ansioso por concederlo. Como resultado, muchos de ellos todavÌa no tienen documentos permanentes.

Disidentes cubanos en EspaÒa protestan durante una manifestaciÛn en las afueras de la embajada de Cuba en Madrid.

La semana pasada me reunÌ con 10 de ellos aquÌ. Su narraciÛn de los aÒos en los calabozos de Cuba y de la represiÛn en la isla ponen los pelos de punta. Uno de ellos me mostrÛ fotos que logrÛ sacar a escondidas de la conocida prisiÛn Combinado del Este, una instalaciÛn sucia e infestada que no es apta para animales. Algunos prisioneros de conciencia han pasado aÒos allÌ.

Luego de tres dÌas de esas entrevistas, comencÈ a ceder bajo el peso de la realidad cubana. Pero la nube que oscureciÛ mi espÌritu no fue provocada por nada que esos patriotas hayan revelado sobre ese agujero infernal conocido como Cuba. Estoy bien informada de la trayectoria en cuanto a derechos humanos de los hermanos Castro. La parte verdaderamente angustiante de las historias que contaron los prisioneros tiene que ver con el papel moralmente en bancarrota interpretado por el gobierno socialista del presidente de gobierno espaÒol, JosÈ Luis RodrÌguez Zapatero, al ayudar a la dictadura cubana para disfrazar la deportaciÛn como "liberaciÛn". Es algo que se podrÌa esperar de los hombres fuertes en Myanmar, Corea del Norte e Ir·n.

Las duras condiciones en las prisiones cubanas son legendarias, aunque el rÈgimen no ha permitido a ning˙n observador de los derechos humanos visitarlas en m·s de dos dÈcadas. Uno de los exiliados me contÛ sobre una tÈcnica de castigo conocida como "el cangrejo", que dijo que era utilizada con los criminales comunes pero un activista de los derechos humanos en Estados Unidos me asegurÛ que es utilizada con los prisioneros polÌticos. Una esposa es puesta en una muÒeca y la otra en el tobillo opuesto. Otro juego de esposas son puestas en la otra muÒeca y el otro tobillo. Entonces el prisionero, vestido solamente con ropa interior, es arrojado al piso de una celda h˙meda donde permanece un dÌa o m·s. Golpizas, confinamientos en solitario y el acoso a los familiares del preso en su casa son tambiÈn son pr·cticas comunes.

Se supone que este tipo de cosas reducen la disidencia pero luego de siete aÒos de horrible vida en prisiÛn, muchos de "los 75" de los cuales algunos est·n cumpliendo sentencias de m·s de dos dÈcadas, no mostraban seÒales de quebrar su espÌritu. Orlando Zapata Tamayo realizÛ una huelga de hambre y muriÛ a manos del rÈgimen en febrero de 2010. Las golpizas de los matones de los Castro a las Damas de Blanco- las esposas, hermanas y madres de los prisioneros polÌticos- fueron capturadas por telÈfonos celulares y se difundieron r·pidamente por Internet. Otro disidente en huelga de hambre, Guillermo FariÒas, estaba gravemente enfermo.

"Los 75" se han transformado en un enorme problema de relaciones p˙blicas para el rÈgimen. En momentos en que los gobiernos y los intelectuales del mundo condenan las sistem·ticas violaciones a los derechos humanos, era claro que m·s de medio siglo de propaganda cubana promoviendo la imagen del paraÌso socialista, estaba en peligro de desplomarse. Para minimizar el daÒo, el rÈgimen necesitaba no solamente sacar los prisioneros del paÌs, presentando ese paso como una "liberaciÛn" sino tambiÈn asegurar que ser·n olvidados. EspaÒa aceptÛ ayudar y øpor quÈ no? El entonces ministro de Relaciones Exteriores, Miguel ¡ngel Moratinos, tenÌa una c·lida relaciÛn con el gobierno de Castro y era un frecuente huÈsped VIP en la isla.

La mayorÌa de los ex prisioneros polÌticos me dijeron que no querÌan irse de Cuba, pero que el cardenal Jaime Ortega, que actuÛ como un intermediario para la dictadura, los presionÛ a ellos y sus familias. Los familiares, preocupados de que sus seres queridos pudieran morir en prisiÛn, les pidieron que se fueran a EspaÒa.

Una vez en EspaÒa, se dieron cuenta que habÌan sido engaÒados. Eran claramente refugiados polÌticos, y bajo la ley espaÒola tenÌan derecho a reclamar ser considerados como tales. Pero el que EspaÒa admitiera que eran vÌctimas de persecuciÛn polÌtica serÌa negar el objetivo de todo esto, que era pintar a Castro como un gran humanitario que los liberÛ. Esa es la razÛn por la que muchos de aquellos con los que hablÈ permanecen en un limbo legal.

La transiciÛn a la democracia en Cuba depende de dos cosas: nuevos lÌderes en el paÌs y solidaridad internacional con la libertad en el extranjero. Zapatero ha traicionado al pueblo cubano en ambos aspectos.

Spain Betrays Cuba's Dissidents 

President JosÈ Zapatero helped Castro get rid of the best leaders of the island's nascent democracy movement. JUNE 13, 2011

By MARY ANASTASIA O'GRADY



Madrid

Despite 21% unemployment and a looming debt crisis, Spain is still considered one of the world's great travel destinations. That is unless you are a Cuban prisoner of conscience who was deported and dumped here by the military dictatorship in Havana. In that case, life as an alien on the sunny Iberian Peninsula is economically and psychologically grim. 

Over the past 11 months, the Cuban regime has abruptly removed 115 political prisoners from their jail cells and banished them to Spain, calling their exile "liberation." Many of them are part of a group known as "the 75," who were arrested in March 2003 for activities like collecting signatures on a democracy petition, leading peaceful marches, or writing for independent newspapers. They were permitted to leave with their immediate families and bring one change of clothes from Cuba, but they were not given the chance to say goodbye to friends and extended family and were issued no papers. A number of them have tried to claim political-refugee status, but the Spanish government has not been eager to grant it. As a result, many of them still have no permanent documents. 

Last week I met with 10 of them here. Their stories of years in Cuba's dungeons and of the wider repression across the island are hair-raising. One of them showed me smuggled photos from inside the notorious Combinado del Este prison, a filthy, infested facility not fit for animals. Some prisoners of conscience have spent years there. 



Cuban dissidents rally outside the Cuban Embassy in Madrid on Feb 26, the anniversary of the death of political prisoner Orlando Zapata Tamayo.

After three days of these interviews, I began to slump under the weight of the Cuban reality. But the cloud that darkened my spirit was not brought on by anything these patriots had revealed about the hell-hole known as Cuba. I am well-versed in Castro's human rights record. The truly distressing part of the prisoners' stories is the morally bankrupt role played by the Socialist government of Spanish President JosÈ Luis RodrÌguez Zapatero in assisting the Cuban dictatorship to disguise the deportation as "liberation." It's what one might expect from the bosses in Burma, North Korea or Iran.

The harsh prison conditions in Cuba are legendary, though the regime has not allowed any human rights observer to have a look in more than two decades. One of the exiles told me about a punishment technique called "the crab," which he said is used on common criminals but one human rights activist in the U.S. told me is also used on political prisoners. One handcuff is put on one wrist and the other handcuff is put on the opposite ankle. Another set of handcuffs is put on the other wrist and ankle. Then the prisoner, wearing only underwear, is tossed onto the floor of a dank cell where he may remain for a day or more. Beatings, solitary confinement and harassment of family members at home are also common practices.



This kind of stuff is supposed to curb dissent but after seven years of grisly prison life, many of "the 75," a number of whom were serving sentences of more than two decades, showed no signs of cracking. Orlando Zapata Tamayo went on a hunger strike and died at the hands of the regime in February 2010. The beatings by Castro thugs of the Ladies in White-the wives, sisters and mothers of the political prisoners-were captured on cellphones and went viral on the Web. Another hunger-striking dissident, Guillermo Farinas, was gravely ill. 



"The 75" had become a huge public-relations problem for the regime. As governments and intellectuals around the world condemned the systematic brutality, it was clear that more than a half-century of Cuban propaganda promoting the socialist paradise image was in danger of going down the drain. To minimize the damage, the regime needed not only to get the prisoners out of the country under the headline of "liberation," but also to ensure that they would land in oblivion. Spain agreed to help, and why not? Then-Foreign Minister Miguel Moratinos has a warm relationship with the Castro government and was a frequent VIP guest on the island. 

Most of the former prisoners told me that they did not want to leave Cuba, but Cardinal Jaime Ortega, who acted as a go-between for the dictatorship, pressured them and their families. Family members, worried that their loved ones might die in prison, asked them to take the Spanish exit. 

Once in Spain, they realized they'd been had. They were clearly political refugees, and under Spanish law they were entitled to claim that designation. But for Spain to admit that they were victims of political persecution would negate the whole point of the exercise, which was to paint Castro as a great humanitarian who had set them free. This is why many of those I spoke with remain in legal limbo. 

The transition to democracy in Cuba depends on two things: New leaders at home and international solidarity with their struggle for liberty from abroad. Mr. Zapatero has betrayed the Cuban people on both fronts.

Write to O'Grady@...

June 14, for the freedom of Oscar LÛpez Rivera

Editorial 
Published: Tuesday June 7, 2011 
http://www.claridadpuertorico.com/content.html?news=6AA6865BAC0E885B342E2900E7E5EAA2
 
It is important that the president of the United States, Barack Obama, knows that not everyone in Puerto Rico will receive him with blessings on June 14. It is necessary for him to understand that thousands of Puerto Rican men and women will take advantage of his ìpro formaî fleeting visit to our Homeland to remind him that in the prison in Terre Haute, in the state of Indiana, a good decent man, a patriot and combatant for the independence of Puerto Rico named Oscar LÛpez Rivera, has spent 30 consecutive years in prison, becoming the Puerto Rican political prisoner who has served the most time in prison in the United States, and one of the longest held political prisoners in our hemisphere. It is also necessary to remind him that now the release of our political prisoner depends on his granting him clemency, after the system viciously denied him relief by way of parole.
 
Oscar LÛpez Rivera has served more time in prison for the ideal of freedom for Puerto Rico than even Nelson Mandela, who was the most famous and acclaimed political prisoner of the 20th century, victorious symbol of the struggle against apartheid in South Africa and icon of the struggle for civil and human rights of all humankind.
 
Barack Obama knows why Oscar LÛpez Rivera is in prison. He knows what has been the motivation of Oscar and the other combatants, prisoners and martyrs for the freedom of our Homeland; he knows they are prepared to make sacrifices and he knows the high cost they have paid and are paying for the discrimination, persecution and repression by the repressive apparatus of the state in Puerto Rico and the United States. He knows enough about our history to know that Puerto Rico was invaded by the armed forces of his country in 1898 in an act of war, and that since then it has been a colony of the United States. He knows that the so-called Free Associated State has not resolved our colonial problem, because the ultimate political power over Puerto Rican affairs continues to reside in the Congress of the United States. He is aware of the victorious struggle of our people to oust the U.S. Navy from Culebra and Vieques. He grasps the strength of our identity and our culture, which has prevailed in spite of all the attempts at assimilation. For all these reasons, he should know that trying to resolve a wrong so deep and so real as the colonial situation of Puerto Rico through a bureaucratic entity known as the White House Interagency Group is a lack of respect for Oscar LÛpez Rivera and for the thousands of Puerto Rican men and woman who strive to get the United States government to assume its responsibility for the definitive remediation of said wrong with seriousness and intelligence.
 
For these same reasons, we at CLARIDAD would have preferred that, on the occasion of Barack Obamaís visit to Puerto Rico, the Patriotic Movement and progressive forces of the country could have reached an agreement to have one sole activity with all sectors participating, with the only demand being that President Obama immediately release Puerto Rican political prisoner 
Oscar LÛpez Rivera. To have gathered all together behind the cohesive figure of Oscar would have been the most forceful way to capture our peopleís yearning for freedom in the presence of the U.S. leader, and to recreate among us the example of unselfishness and generosity that our imprisoned patriot has shown us. Itís really a shame that internal differences within the Patriotic Movement have gotten in the way of such a unitary and massive demonstration.
 
However, in the two activities scheduled to protest Obamaís visit, the demand that the President of the United States immediately release Puerto Rican political prisoner Oscar LÛpez Rivera will be present in a prominent way. Achieving his release should have priority as an urgent goal, for those of us who share his patriotic idea, as well as for those who for humanitarian reasons believe that he has been in prison for too long. Thus, CLARIDAD, the Newspaper of the Puerto Rican Nation, invites all Puerto Rican men and women of good will to join, with their posters for the release of Oscar LÛpez Rivera, the activities that will convene for the visit of the president of the United States, Barack Obama, next Tuesday, June 14, in Old San Juan.

 
 
 
Tito Kayak arrested for protesting against Obama 
Negotiates his decent from pole if police release those arrested 

By Frances Rosario / frosario1@... 
June 13, 2011

http://www.elnuevodia.com/protestatitokayakcontralavisitadeobama-990611.html 
 
Environmental activist Alberto de Jes˙s, better known as "Tito Kayakî was forced down from the pole where he was protesting against president Barack Obama and was immediately arrested by police. 
 
Presently is not known to what police precinct he has been taken and whether charges will be filed for demonstration on pole on Rom·n Baldorioty de Castro Avenue. 
 
De Jesus climbed the pole in the early morning hours to display a sign in English in which he asks for the freedom of political prisoner Oscar Lopez Rivera. 
 
ì30 years is too muchî, read the sign.
 
Following hours atop the pole, De Jesus took off the mask  which covered his face and at about 7:45 a.m. began negotiating his descend. He asked the police for the release of those arrested in order to come down it was reported by radio station  NotiUno. 
 
It is still not known if the police agreed to his request. the fact is that the man was lowered by a crane of the Emergency Services of the San Juan police and was arrested. 
 
According to police reports six persons were arrested before Jesus. 
 
Those arrested were transported to the headquarters of the Transit Division in San Juan for processing said  Figueroa Sancha. 
 
"There has to be consultation with the prosecutor about what's occurred. As long as communications are flowing they can demonstrate for or against with dignity and order," the Superintendent stated in a radio interview (NotiUno). 
 
Figueroa Sancha pointed out that acts such as these upon the arrival of Obama on Tuesday could lead to federal charges.  
 
He emphasised that demonstrators cannot be allowed disrupt the passing of the presidential caravan. 



 

 
 
Report from Avelino Gonzalez Claudio's Discretionary Parole Hearing 
 
 
To: My Wife, Children, Family and Friends,
 
On May 27, 2011, I went to a hearing to see if they would grant me a discretionary parole prior to Mandatory Parole. Discretionary parole covers the period after serving 28 months of my sentence. After 56 months comes the mandatory parole. The hearing was attended by the hearing examiner and two prison officials: the case manager and his supervisor. 
 
The hearing examiner explained that it was better if I signed a request to waive the hearing at the time, as there was a slim chance that Iíd be granted parole. He said it was better to wait for the hearing on Mandatory Parole, which would be held on or before May of 2012. That was ìoff the record,î as he hadnít turned on the recorder that makes the hearing official.
 
It was when I told him I preferred to go ahead with the hearing anyway that I understood his intentions. He posited that due to the fact that my sentence was very light compared to the serious nature of the offense, he wasnít going to recommend parole. Then he tried time after time to get me to admit my participation in the events at Sabana Seca and in the mortar attack on the federal court in San Juan, as a member of the Central Committee and the Board of Directors of the Macheteros.
 
I responded that I wasnít convicted of those actions, and that my position had been explained in the plea agreement arrived at with the prosecutors, and that it was an integral part of my sentence. He said he didnít know about the plea agreement with the prosecutors, and that his position was based on the Pre-Sentence Report.
 
He indicated that his evaluation was based on my participation in the two events: Sabana Seca and the attack on the federal court. According to his evaluation, the classification he was going to give me was 8 (eight), which was the classification of highest danger that exists and which is the equivalent of first degree murder. He was going to submit his recommendation to the Parole Commission, and in 21 days, more or less, they would notify me of the Commissionís decision.

  "ChÌcharos"... acabaditos de colar



  Actualizado: 14 de Junio de 2011 - 11:34 pm 

  EconomÌa

  ChÌcharos acabaditos de colar

  Roberto ¡lvarez QuiÒones

  Los ¡ngeles

  | 13-06-2011 - 6:12 pm.

    a.. CafÈ
    b.. Cuba
   

  En 1958 Cuba produjo 60.000 toneladas de cafÈ, por solo 6.300 en 2011.



  Un trabajador en una planta de cafÈ en La Habana. (REUTERS, abril de 2011)

   

  "No se vaya todavÌa, Paco, que le voy a traer una tacita de chÌcharos acabaditos de colar". Por incomprensible que parezca, esta frase podrÌa ser hoy cotidiana en Cuba si el gobierno castrista no insistiese en llamar cafÈ a la mezcla de un 50% del arom·tico y estimulante grano con otro 50% de chÌcharos tostados y molidos.

  A propÛsito de anunciar el rÈgimen, el pasado 3 de mayo, que se vuelve a la mezcla de ambos granos luego de entregar a la poblaciÛn durante poco tiempo cafÈ vietnamita -de inferior  calidad y mayor contenido de cafeÌna-, la OrganizaciÛn Internacional del CafÈ (OIC), con sede en Londres, reiterÛ que todo cafÈ que tenga m·s de un 5% de mezcla con otros granos no puede llamarse cafÈ. AsÌ de simple.

  Esto contrasta con la fama que tuvo Cuba durante unos 160 aÒos como naciÛn productora y exportadora de uno de los mejores cafÈs del mundo, sobre todo el ar·bigo suave de la variedad Bourbon, cosechado en las montaÒas orientales , donde un microclima especial favorece la producciÛn  de un grano de extraordinaria calidad.

  Seg˙n el propio Ministerio de Agricultura cubano, en los aÒos 40 el paÌs era uno de los mayores exportadores mundiales de un cafÈ que era muy apreciado internacionalmente. En 1958 el paÌs produjo 60.000 toneladas, es decir un millÛn de sacos de 60 kilogramos, equivalentes a 132,2 millones de libras, que divididas entre los seis millones de habitantes de entonces arrojÛ 1,8 libras de cafÈ mensuales por cada cubano.

  Pero llegÛ el Comandante con su socialismo "y mandÛ a parar". Y de quÈ manera: en la ˙ltima cosecha (2010-2011) Cuba produjo 6.300 toneladas de cafÈ, la dÈcima parte de lo que se cosechaba cuando el paÌs era "explotado" por el capitalismo.

  De exportadores de lujo a importadores baratos

  En octubre de 1966, dÌas despuÈs de que el ciclÛn InÈs azotara las zonas cafetaleras de la Sierra Cristal, en Oriente, fui con un grupo de estudiantes de periodismo a esa regiÛn montaÒosa, rebautizada en 1958 por Fidel Castro como Segundo Frente Oriental "Frank PaÌs". Nuestra misiÛn era tratar de convencer a los cafetaleros privados de que uniesen sus fincas -en cooperativas en vez de trabajarlas individualmente- para asÌ "aprovechar mejor los recursos y aumentar la producciÛn".

  Adem·s de lo bien que la pasamos mis colegas y yo entre aquella formidable gente de campo durante un mes, viviendo en la meseta de La Caoba y moviÈndonos a caballo o a pie por aquellas hermosas montaÒas, recuerdo muy bien dos cosas: 1) que sÛlo uno de las decenas de campesinos  que entrevistÈ me dijo que iba a "pensar" lo de la cooperativizaciÛn; y 2) el pronÛstico que algunos de ellos me hicieron de que con los controles impuestos ya por el Estado y el bajo precio que recibÌan por cada lata (44 libras) de cafÈ cosechado, la producciÛn cafetalera iba a continuar cayendo.



  (De La Caoba tampoco se me olvidar· la curiosa forma en que llegaba a all· arriba el diario "Granma": desde un aviÛn era lanzado cada dÌa un paquete de varios periÛdicos que siempre caÌa en el parquecito que allÌ habÌa. Y obviamente no olvidarÈ que allÌ me llegÛ un telegrama con la noticia de que habÌa nacido  mi primer hijo).

  Poco tiempo despuÈs, a fines de los 60, Mario GarcÌa Inch·ustegui  -el embajador ante la ONU a quien en 1962 le "tocÛ" hacer el ridÌculo de negar que en Cuba habÌa misiles nucleares-, director del departamento de Organismos Internacionales del Ministerio del Comercio Exterior (MINCEX), me confesÛ off the record que en las sesiones de la OIC en Londres ya no estaban haciendo efecto los pretextos para justificar el incumplimiento de la cifra de exportaciÛn que le asignaba a Cuba esa organizaciÛn, que regulaba la oferta y la demanda mundial de cafÈ mediante un sistema de cuotas de exportaciÛn para cada paÌs miembro, y evitar asÌ la caÌda de los precios.

  Inch·ustegui se referÌa a los ciclones y otras afectaciones clim·ticas esgrimidas por las delegaciones cubanas por Èl presididas para tratar de enmascarar el descalabro cafetalero. "Yo insisto en los argumentos, pero ya no me creen", dijo. Y con gran frustraciÛn, me informÛ que la OIC ya habÌa clasificado a la de Cuba como una "cuota de papel", paso previo que daba esa entidad para luego suprimir dicha cuota y repartirla entre otros paÌses exportadores que pedÌan  aumentar sus ventas.

  En resumen, que tal y como me auguraron los cafetaleros orientales, la intervenciÛn estatal comunista provocÛ un cataclismo. De gran exportador de un grano de excelente calidad, el paÌs pasÛ a ser un importador neto de cafÈ barato.

  Hoy, mediante la cartilla de racionamiento, se le entrega a cada persona una cuota mensual de 115 gramos (un cuarto de libra). Pero como viene mezclado con un 50% de chÌcharos, lo que recibe realmente cada cubano son 57.5 gramos de cafÈ al mes, comparados con los 828 gramos per c·pita mensuales de 1958.

  Y aquÌ hay que agregar un importante detalle. Por su mayor densidad, el chÌcharo tostado y molido tupe los coladores de las cafeteras domÈsticas, razÛn por la cual estallan con frecuencia. Recuerdo los casos de amistades mias que en los aÒos 90 sufrieron quemaduras provocadas por cafeteras que  explotaron.

  El verdadero nÈctar negro, como tambiÈn se le conoce, lo toman los extranjeros, la nomenklatura  y quienes reciben remesas de sus familiares en el exterior y pueden pagar 6.25 dÛlares por libra en las shopping, en un paÌs donde el salario promedio es de 18 dÛlares mensuales.

  Cuando ya las cosechas habÌan descendido a niveles Ìnfimos, la soluciÛn que se le ocurriÛ a Castro fue el llamado "cordÛn de La Habana". RodeÛ la capital con cafetos de la variedad caturra, un cafÈ de sol que se cultivaba en Brasil, sin tener en cuenta que los suelos y el clima eran diferentes, y que las plantaciones brasileÒas no eran atendidas por empleados de oficinas y estudiantes "voluntarios". El fracaso fue colosal y pasÛ a integrar el abultado inventario de disparates del Comandante en Jefe.

  De un rendimiento entre 0.36 y 0.40 toneladas de cafÈ por hect·rea en 1958, seg˙n el Ministerio de Agricultura hoy se cosechan en Cuba de 0.11 a 0.12 toneladas por hect·rea. La productividad se contrajo en casi un 70%. De las 80.700 hect·reas de cafÈ registradas, de acuerdo con el diario Granma, sÛlo 68.600 est·n en producciÛn.

  Lo peor es que debido a su patolÛgico af·n por controlarlo todo, el rÈgimen castrista no enfrenta  con valentÌa la crisis ni siquiera dentro de los lÌmites del propio sistema. Si el gobierno liberase a los caficultores privados (unos 38.000) de las trabas estatales, y les pagase sÛlo un tercio del precio que paga por el cafÈ robusta que importa, que se cotiza entre 1,25 y 1,35 dÛlares la libra, la producciÛn se dispararÌa.

  AsÌ ocurriÛ en Vietnam -oficialmente comunista- donde desde 1986 se permitiÛ a los agricultores sembrar y vender libremente lo cosechado a precios de mercado. Y de importador de cafÈ, Vietnam se convirtiÛ en el segundo productor y exportador mundial del grano, por encima de Colombia y sÛlo detr·s de Brasil.

  Pero los Castro no est·n dispuestos a hacer lo mismo.

Subject:Yahoo! NEWS:   Michelle Obama heads to Africa, stirs criticism  By Rachel Rose Hartman rachel Rose Hartman

Michelle Obama heads to Africa, stirs criticism
By Rachel Rose Hartman rachel Rose Hartman 1 hr 38 mins ago 



First Lady Michelle Obama embarks today on a weeklong trip to Africa to spread goodwill. But the trip is already stirring criticism, making it just the latest travel choice by the First Lady to draw some negative press for the White House.

The aim of Obama's tour, which will take her to South Africa and Botswana, is to engage with young people--especially girls and women--who play prominent roles in academic life and civic leadership, while also furthering awareness on health and wellness issues.

But, as Washington Post writer Krissah Thompson notes, the trip is already provoking disappointment from Africa advocates who argue that President Obama, whose father was Kenyan, hasn't devoted enough time to the continent since winning the presidency. Mwiza Munthali, public outreach director of TransAfrica Forum, argues that U.S. officials "are not seeing Africa as a big priority. There has been some ambivalence." The president has made just one trip to sub-Saharan Africa since his Jan. 2009 inauguration and has chosen not to accompany his wife on her journey.

This isn't the first time the First Lady has come under fire for travel plans. Below we review some of Michelle Obama's past controversies around trips:

. The glitzy Spanish getaway: The First Lady raised eyebrows last August when she decided to jaunt off to Spain, commanding top-dollar luxury accommodations in the middle of a recession. The New York Daily News called her "a modern-day Marie Antoinette."

. The greeting leaders with creative diplomacy in England, Indonesia: The ever-delicate question of international etiquette has made trouble for the First Lady on a couple of foreign trips. In April 2009, she broke royal protocol and hugged Queen Elizabeth, causing a major stir in England and elsewhere. Then in Indonesia last November, Michelle Obama shook the hand of a conservative Muslim minister, a form of social contact between the sexes that violated his religious vows. He blamed the First Lady for the violation.

. The visit to immigration-complicated Mexico: Critics accused the First Lady of organizing a frivolous trip to Mexico in April 2010 with Jill Biden, wife of Vice President Joe Biden. While that trip, too, was aimed primarily on establishing contact with younger civic leaders, some detractors called out the First Lady for taking time to travel to a country that's long been a flashpoint in U.S. immigration policy. Conservative blogger Michelle Malkin, for instance, argued that the trip was little more than an effort to promote "illegal alien shamnesty."

(Photo of Michelle Obama: Chris Carlson/AP)

http://news.yahoo.com/s/yblog_theticket/20110620/ts_yblog_theticket/michelle-obama-heads-to-africa-stirs-criticism/print

Un caso hasta m·s enfermizo le correspondiÛ al ahora ex presidente del Fondo Monetario Internacional, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, a quien se acusÛ de intento de violaciÛn de una camarera en un hotel neoyorquino. 

              Otros hechos tuvieron lÌneas difusas entre el sexo y el dinero, acabando con las aspiraciones de los involucrados. Como las mentiras del senador John Edwards, quien habrÌa usado fondos de la campaÒa electoral para tapar una relaciÛn e hijo extramaritales, mientras su esposa batallaba contra un c·ncer que terminÛ por vencerla en diciembre. O las del gobernador de Carolina del Sur, Mark Sanford, quien acabÛ confesando que usaba dineros p˙blicos para visitar a su amante en Argentina, mientras su seÒora y electores lo creÌan de vacaciones. 

              En AmÈrica Latina no es que los polÌticos reh˙yan los lÌos de faldas, pero no ocasionan polÈmicas mayores. La cultura machista diluye pormenores, calla denuncias y todo lo convierte en anÈcdotas y chacota. Las infidelidades o desviaciones sexuales no cortan carreras polÌticas ni activan renuncias. Los ejemplos sobran. AsÌ sean las aventuras sexuales del ex obispo catÛlico y presidente del Paraguay, Fernando Lugo; las infidelidades y tardanza de Alejandro Toledo y Carlos Menem para reconocer a sus hijos fuera del matrimonio o las evasivas de Daniel Ortega sobre las imputaciones de violaciÛn sexual que le hizo su hijastra. 

              En los paÌses desarrollados tambiÈn algunos polÌticos logran inmunidad sexual. AsÌ sobrevive el italiano Silvio Berlusconi, pese a sus filmadas orgÌas con menores, o resistiÛ Bill Clinton, argumentando que el coito oral con MÛnica Lewinsky no era sexo. Tampoco en estos paÌses del llamado primer mundo se pueden descartar problemas de fraude y corrupciÛn, pero son delitos m·s perseguidos. En general, la corrupciÛn est· m·s enquistada en la actividad privada que en la administraciÛn p˙blica, debido a una mejor cultura de transparencia y m·s regulaciones sobre rendiciÛn de cuentas en el manejo de recursos p˙blicos. Los problemas suceden con m·s frecuencia en compaÒÌas privadas, a travÈs de personajes estilo Madoff o en las multinacionales que sobornan en el extranjero, como la sueca Skanka en Argentina, la noruega Discovery Petroleum en Per˙ o la la estadounidense Dole en Colombia. 

              En realidad no importa tanto que la corrupciÛn estÈ ligada a delitos econÛmicos, libidos desbocados o a faltas Èticas; lo importante es que los ciudadanos deben exigir conductas ejemplares, como la renuncia de Weiner, para que se incentive una cultura de mayor honestidad en la funciÛn p˙blica. 

              La gran diferencia sobre la conducta corrupta por mentiras, sexo o dinero, no radica tanto en sus causas, como sÌ en el nivel de severidad y eficiencia judicial con la que se castiga y trata de controlar.

Subject:Lo que los socialistas no nos perdonan ni reconocen   Dr. Manuel Cereijo, P.E.
